text: <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Expression Is Induced by Degraded CGN and Is Responsible for Monocytes Aggregation In Vitro

text: In order to study the effect of dCGN on the expression of cell surface antigens , PBM and THP-1 cells were incubated for 36 h in the presence and absence of dCGN .
The expression of various cell surface molecules was analyzed by flow cytometry as described in materials and methods .
Both forms of dCGN clearly stimulated expression of <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CD54 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) on PBM and THP-1 cells ( Fig . 4A ) .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_0> Positive_regulation stimulated <extra_id_0> Theme expression <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Gene_expression expression <extra_id_0> Theme ICAM-1 <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1>

text: The increase in <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression was higher on THP-1 cells treated with 40 kDa dCGN ( Fig . 4B ) .

text: Another surface antigen , the <extra_id_0> lymphocyte function-associated antigen 3 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> CD58 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) was slightly reduced on PBM after treatment with 40 kDa dCGN ( Fig . 4B ) .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_0> Negative_regulation reduced <extra_id_0> Theme lymphocyte function-associated antigen 3 <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1>

text: Interestingly , expression of major histocompatibility complex molecules of class I ( HLA-ABC ) and of class II ( HLA-DR ) , as well as the <extra_id_0> monocyte marker <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> CD14 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , seemed to be reduced by treatment with dCGN ( Fig . 4B ) .
event: <extra_id_0> <extra_id_0> Gene_expression expression <extra_id_0> Theme CD14 <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> Negative_regulation reduced <extra_id_0> Theme expression <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1> <extra_id_1>

text: However , these differences were not statistically significant .
Treatment with dCGN also induced a strong aggregation of monocytes , detected by phase contrast inverse microscopy ( Fig . 5 ) .

Although this effect was easily observed in monocytes incubated with the 10 kDa dCGN ( Fig . 5B ) , a more robust cell aggregation was observed in monocytes incubated with the 40 kDa dCGN ( Fig . 5C ) .
<extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been proposed to be the main adhesion molecule responsible for monocyte aggregation .
To confirm this , monocytes were incubated with both types of dCGN in the presence of an anti-ICAM-1 antibody , an anti-CD58 antibody and an isotype control IgG1 antibody .

The anti-ICAM-1 antibody effectively blocked the cell aggregates induced by dCGN ( Fig . 5D , 5E ) , strongly suggesting that indeed <extra_id_0> ICAM-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is responsible for monocyte aggregation .
Both the control IgG1 and the anti-CD58 antibody did not modify monocyte aggregation ( data not shown ) .
